Authors:
Tatiana I Sanjuan, Ana Esperanza Franco-Molano, Ryan
Michael kepler, RM, Javier Felipe Tabima, Joseph W. Spatafora, Aida
Vasco, Silvia Restrepo
Title:
Five new species of entomopathogenic fungi from the Amazon in
the phylogenetic context of Ophiocordyceps
Keywords:
Ascomycota, host specificity, Formicidae, Dyctioptera,
Neotropical taxonomy
Abstract:
The Neotropical biogeographic zone is one of the âhot
spotsâ of global biodiversity. In addition to insects, the
entomopathogenic fungal genus Ophiocordyceps is species rich in the
Amazon region with initial descriptions dating to the early nineteenth
century. The molecular phylogenetic status of many Amazonian species of
Ophiocordyceps are poorly studied, however, and their integration into
molecular phylogenetic analyses of Ophiocordycipitaceae is necessary for
a more robust phylogenetic assessment of the genus and the family. We
conducted a survey in the Amazon subregion of Colombia in the
biogeographic provinces of Napo and Imeri. Including also some samples
from Amazon subregion of Ecuador; Choco and Magdalena provinces from
Caribe subregion. Morphological examinations complemented molecular
phylogenetic analyses of five nuclear loci including SSU, LSU, TEF, RPB1
and RPB2. Thirty-five specimens were examinedrepresenting fifteen
different species of Ophiocordyceps;and five new species:O.
blattarioides, O. tiputini, O. araracuarensis, O. fugoromorphila and O.
evansii were described.Accurate identification of the host allowed us to
hypothesize that host identity and host habitat is positively correlate
with phylogenetic species of Ophiocordyceps and is likely a strong
driver in speciation of neotropical entomopathogenic fungi.
